title: Migraine-Type Headache in a Middle-Aged Executive
clinical_history: Mr. Jonathan Li is a 42-year-old male, working as a senior finance manager at a multinational firm. He presented with complaints of recurring headaches for the past 8 months, gradually increasing in frequency and intensity. The headaches are typically unilateral, starting above the right eye and radiating to the right temple and occiput. He describes the pain as throbbing and moderate-to-severe in intensity. The headaches are often accompanied by photophobia, phonophobia, and occasional nausea, but no vomiting. The pain is usually worse in the late afternoon, especially after prolonged screen time, meetings, or periods of high stress. Notably, he reports increased pericranial muscle tenderness, particularly in the upper trapezius and suboccipital region on the right. He denies aura or visual disturbances. Sleep is interrupted by headache on 1-2 nights per week. OTC analgesics provide some relief.

nprs.affected_area: Right frontotemporal and occipital region (headache proper)
Upper trapezius and suboccipital muscles (referred muscular pain)

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged computer use, mental stress, poor posture, missed meals, inadequate hydration, lack of sleep, exposure to bright light or loud noise.
picture: [insert image showing right-sided head (frontotemporal and occipital), upper trapezius, and suboccipital muscle areas]
easing_factors: Resting in a dark quiet room, gentle neck stretches, application of a cold pack to forehead, over-the-counter NSAIDs, reducing screen time.
past_history: No previous significant neurological conditions. Occasional tension headaches during university years, which were self-limited.
medical_history: Mild hypertension, diagnosed 3 years ago and controlled on medication. No history of head trauma or sinus disease.
medications: Lisinopril 10mg daily (for hypertension). Ibuprofen 400mg as needed for headache, taken 2-3 times per week.
personal_history: Married, two children (aged 9 and 11). High job stress due to demanding deadlines. Sleeps 5-6 hours per night. Low physical activity due to work commitments. No recreational drug use, occasional alcohol on weekends.
imaging: None to date; clinical diagnosis with no red flag features detected.
